Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Exosomal tRNA fragments may constitute an innate viral defense against SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory RNA viruses.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: Viral infection can induce formation of specific transfer RNA fragments (tRFs) that are packaged and released from host cells in exosomes. The project aims to discover the biological role of exosomal tRFs, specifically investigating whether uptake of these tRFs into uninfected cells triggers an innate antiviral immune response against SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory RNA viruses. New insights into the influence of tRFs on host defense mechanisms against viral infections could be exploited to combat COVID-19 and future outbreaks of related viruses. The project also offers training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, the latter through bioinformatics course-based research.<br/><br/>The project is based on preliminary data suggesting that tRF exosomal delivery constitutes a novel mechanism of innate antiviral immunity whereby tRFs prime host cells for a more robust interferon response. The research on SARS-CoV-2 will be guided by specific questions, for example, about the extent of exosomal tRF uptake and bioavailability in recipient cells, whether the tRFs hybridize with viral RNAs and activate interferon production through association with RIG-I, and whether intracellular tRFs inhibit viral replication in cells. Characterization of a novel host defense mechanism could potentially inform strategies for therapeutic intervention against COVID-19. <br/><br/>This RAPID award is jointly funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
BROADER IMPACTS

In addition to potential value in terms of several NSF-noted, societally relevant, broader impact outcomes (e.g. improved well-being of individuals in society; improved national security; and increased economic competitiveness of the U.S.), the proposed work also included significant graduate and undergraduate training opportunities both in the laboratory and through incorporating a markedly successful, Course Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) previously developed by the PI. Importantly, the Fall 2020 and 2021 sections of this course participated in and executed a project dovetailing nicely with the proposed Aims. Undergraduates in these sections collaboratively mined available SRA vesicle small RNA-Seq datasets in order to generate a comprehensive catalog of extracellular vesicle tRF profiles culminating in their co-authorship on a research article originally published as a bioRxiv preprint and currently in revision for Nature Communications:

Dominika Houserovaꭞ, Yulong Huang*, Mohan V. Kasukurthiꭞ, Brianna C. Watters*, Fiza F. Khan*, Raj V. Mehta*, Neil Y. Chaudhary*, Justin T. Robertsꭞ, Jeffrey D. DeMeisꭞ, Trevor K. Hobbs*, Kanesha R. Ghee*, Cameron H. McInnis*, Nolan P. Johns*, Abrianna J. Kegler*, Alexander B. Coleyꭞ, Cana L. Brown*, Jenny L. Hewesꭞ, Marie M. McElyea*, Monica N. Reeves*, Tuan M. Tran, Natalie R. Bauer, Jingshan Huang, Jonathon P. Audia, John W. Foster, Glen M. Borchert. Salmonella Outer Membrane Vesicles contain tRNA Fragments (tRFs) that Inhibit Bacteriophage P22 infection. bioRxiv 2021 Nov 9: 467952; doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.11.09.467952 *undergraduate; ꭞgraduate student/postdoc

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Notably, despite there being several published reports independently describing (1) the marked prevalence of tRFs within extracellular vesicle transcriptomes and (2) roles for specific tRFs in facilitating/inhibiting viral replication, prior to this study there had been no examinations of the effects of vesicle-secreted tRFs on viral replication reported to date. In addition to confirming that overexpressing a tRF (complementary to several RNA viruses including Influenza B and VEEV (Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis Virus)) in BHK-21 (hamster kidney) cells can inhibit VEEV replication in vitro, we surprisingly also found bacterial cells similarly secrete tRFs in vesicles, that these tRFs are also highly complementary to viruses (phage), and that these tRFs are similarly capable of inhibiting viral replication. Importantly, the characterization of the ability of vesicle-secreted tRFs to inhibit viral replication achieved in this project will help pioneer this field of investigation and strongly suggests that vesicle-secreted tRFs constitute an ancient, but hitherto unrecognized form of innate viral defense potentially exploitable as novel broad spectrum antivirals.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Glen M Borchert
